Would easily pay 3 times the price! Hacknet gave me a great experience! The game let's you explore network systems by utilizing a variety of tools to crack systems, files, explore networks. You exploit system flaws while looking for human error all while following a very mystical and wellmade storyline that gives the game a touch of crime roman feeling to it. It's always something new around the next corner and it never gets boring. You got quite good control over the pace of the game and there's always a variety of things to choose from. Stylish and authentic, Hacknet doesn't do the work for you, and instead empowers you to tackle problems for yourself. If you loved Uplink, get on this.

They got three locked ports. You begin the port attacking... the screen is getting red, your time is running out. Your RAM is maxed out trying to open two of them. The red is down halfway the screen! You do the last one... then porhack... YOU'RE IN! Wait.. you need to manually type your own IP?! Your eyes dart all over and spot it next to your username. The red is past 3/4ths way down, your fingers quiver as you try to type it correctly and quickly. Almost everything is red! where do you- flashing button 'Assign New IP'! Click-  Disconnected. You wait....  ...  'IP Address successfully rest... Foreign trace averted.... preparing for system reboot....'   Sounds like something from a crazy action movie... this game does this and more.

A very introspective look at UNIX commands and the general actions of hacking - which is basically accurate, but taking out the time required to accomplish these things (for example, you can solve port protocols within a few seconds, but IRL this might take hours).  Basically, if you want the 'reality' where you are the hacker in one of these movies (you're not playing the hacker, but ARE the hacker), then this is pretty spot-on. It just removes most of the tedium of the acitivites. This is not to say that the game isn't repetitive; it is, and remains true to its roots as a simulator. By nature, most simulators run off of repetitive actions which require muscle memory and timing in order to complete.  In actual fact, this is more of a puzzle-solving game. However, combined with some funny easter eggs (IRC chats can get hilarious) and honest-to-god methodology on the principles of hacking, this actually becomes enjoyable unless you just want to shoot things in the face (in which case, this is NOT the game for you).  Anyone who wants to work in software QA should be able to play this game comfortably, figure out most of the puzzles, and genuinely enjoy the experience. If you can't, don't take QA as a career. Because this in almost any form is what you do - all day, every day. I know this from 14 years of experience at that job in everything from game development to SAS or security software.  There are a few points I wish there were more of, or more developed. As game, it's pretty linear. There are nice little things like finding additional information on a server which gives you another terminal to hack, or a phone to break into, but these are too few and far between. It could be far more sandboxy if there were a freeform mode for points, which had sets of systems and connected devices which would allow you to randonly investigate things you found on another system. In this, you'd need a points system or something to gain (money, cred, whatever) - which would be a welcome addition to the game. I think another fun mode would be to actually use the system specs for the computer it was running on for memory, etc. as well as randonly generating in-game groups to become involved with, do missions for (from forums, etc.)  I recommend this game, just due to the simulation nature being captured very well. That being said, this game won't be for everyone. Much of the game is tedium and random investigation - which is exactly what hacking is about. One of the best missions which represents this is the 'Project Junebug' mission. You're basically let loose to figure out how to accomlish the task, you have a lot of reading to do to catch up on how to accomplish it, and there isn't any handholding. YOU have to do the tasks, to the best of your understanding, and figure out indeed, what those tasks are, and it involves multiple servers, and different methods of having the same outcome.

Don't let the terminal screen and techno-nonsense trick you—Hacknet is a deceptively simple game to play. You use a series of commands to 'hack' into terminals both as a contract hacker and on a mission, one to find the reason for a fellow hacker's untimely death.  It's in large part due to its phenomenal soundtrack and well-realised interface, but no game this year has made me feel like more of a badass than Hacknet. Its presentation is executed so well that every action you take feels like you've been doing them for years, like hacking into networks is just child's play.  It plays very much like a puzzle-adventure game, so if something like that is up your alley, it's really worth checking out.  Also, it's worth playing to see the final hacking sequence alone.

Hacknet is the spiritual successor to Introversion Software's 2001 game Uplink. You start with simple 'hack into X and get Y' gameplay but quickly progress to more complicated systems and detective work. The game uses real command line prompts and correct ports, plus it has a fantastic soundtrack and lots of funny files to find if you're thorough when you dig around other people's machines.  Warning: if you are looking for amazing graphics and hate reading walls of text, this isn't the game for you.

Bit has randomly vanished, and it is your job to figure out how. You get recruited into various hacker 'Squads' in hope of finding out more about Bit's disapperence.   The game runs well, and can get pretty intense at times, so if stressful situations isn't really your thing, I'd watch out when playing this.

It's not a simple game of just typing 'hack computer' and waiting for a meter to fill up - you have to do some thinking and looking around and stuff if you want to succeed. If you work with Linux at all, you'll probably find yourself pleasantly surprised by the functionality this game tries to replicate. There's also all sorts of interesting easter eggs and other content to find, even after you've beaten the game once.  One of my favorite games now, definitely. I've just finished Hacknet, and as you can tell by my total playtime (which also includes a profile I didn't quite complete), it's not a very long game. However, I'm quite sure that you will love every minute of it.  I'm not entirely sure how this game stacks up if you just want another Uplink (I haven't played that particular game), but there are other reviews that focus on that. What I can tell you is that this game is a stylish, sleek, and very impressive hacking simulator. The plot is woven very well into the game, and there are easter eggs and hidden things aplenty. I made it a point to look at every IRC archive on every computer I hacked, because I'd be laughing even while they traced my IP address.  The game's solution to everything is elegant and new; nothing feels like a tired concept. The game is just long enough to be as impressive as possible with all of its assets.  On the negative side, the slightly buggy nature of the game is where the indie nature really shows. My first playthrough went well enough until I was hit with a progression-ending bug that I didn't realize until I had actually made progress into a hidden sidequest. From then on, I was a little bit afraid to explore and screw around in case I got hit with another glitch. An option to load from saves wouldn't be amiss, but I'm sure people would use it to save-scum (and unfortunately miss one of Hacknet's coolest features:   attempting to forcibly reset your IP address just after a trace has reached your computer  , which adds to the game's tension).  Some objectives and game aspects are a little unclear, especially when worded in the game's cool cyber-security lingo (which actually adds to the charm to some extent). For instance, there's only a small sliver of documentation about a considerably-important yet optional feature: setting up proxies as 'traps' to be sprung if a trace is about to reach you, which overloads your computer but stops the trace from doing any lasting damage. Experimenting is rendered difficult due to the fear of bugs as above - again, some sort of feature to load a session might help.  However, above all, you will find that Hacknet is well worth your time and $10 (or $8 if you buy during this Steam sale), because - be honest with yourself - you're looking into Hacknet to feel like a Hollywood Hacker, and that's exactly what this game makes you feel like.

The biggest difference is that HN is much more command based than UL where, as far as I remember, most of the things could be done with a mouse. And about UL I honestly love all the references they put in the game, like the password 'rosebud' which, if I'm correct, was the one of the Uplink Server Test Machine!!! Gameplay-wise the game is pretty 'straightforward': you connect to a machine, you use the tools you have available to hack it. The best part is when you'll have to search for a password, 'cause in that case you'll have to use more of your brain instead of just launching this or that tool. CONs: The biggest letdown is that there's no upgrade system (like in UL where you could change your machine, CPU, etc.) and if you combine this with the fact that the missions don't seem randomly generated (again like in UL) you'll see that some people could not have enough motivations to replay the game... unless you're a maniac and want to check every single IRC Log or such stuff. :D Surely most of you could object that it wasn't that great in UL too, 'cause you just needed to find a nice bank, hack it and voilà you had everything upgraded. IT Hacknet è un gran gioco.  Vi è piaciuto Uplink? Bene allora dovrebbe piacervi pure questo gioco. But are we interested in dedicating our freetime for our new and perhaps fleeting passion? Learn to program and hack and learn code and whatever. Books! Math! Boring stuff! Thank God there is Hacknet, a hacking sim reminiscent of the classic game Uplink. And in a good way!  Basically, you are a hacker and you follow a storyline and/or your own ideas and hack your way through files, computer systems, security and whatnot. And, like in real life, the protagonist (you!) sits in front of the computer and does all this incredible hacking stuff from his or her chair. And in a game like this, its about the small things it does: You can click on a computer to connect with it. Or you use command codes and an IP adress. You can look through files with clicking on a button. Or you use, you guessed it, command codes to look through it. The latter feels more authentic, and sometimes, thats what you want. Actually, in my humble opinion, this game is best when you try to use as many written commands as possible. It gives you the feeling to be a real hacker.   In many games, hacking is an afterthought. A minigame at best. Like in Deus Ex: Hacking belongs to Cyberpunk like awesome armblades, but it is basically connect-the-dots with a nicer color palette. And thats totally cool, cause you dont want to obstruct the core gameplay. But if you want to feel like a real hacker, disrupting the system chilling in a comfy chair, then look no further than Hacknet. Choose your nickname, learn a few basic commands that the game teaches you and discover your inner anarchist. The game gets more complicated along the way and you have to think a bit more, but thats what you want. Hacking the computer of a smalltown retirement home is one thing, but getting these corporations: Thats the holy grail of cyberpunk-esque hacking, isnt it? General bugs: This game was moderately interesting, though buggy, for the first hour or so. The keyboard didn't always work, so I couldn't type commands at a rate I was used to. Every once in a while, the keyboard would completely break (you type in a few characters of a command, and the game backspaces them out). However, you could always save, quit the game, and restart to fix it (although the keyboard was always buggy). This was on Mac. I decided to switch to a Windows machine, and the keyboard worked perfectly.  Annoyances: Commands don't work like you'd think. Many of them are close to real commands (e.g. scp). However, you can't download a file to a different filename, like real scp. AFAICT, there is no way to create a directory. For someone who likes organization, being only able to put dozens of random files from different missions into one big directory (or move them into one of two subdirectories already created) was frustrating.  Game-breaking bug: Before I switched platforms, I hit a game-breaking bug on a certain mission where I had to decrypt a file. My research told me what the password should be, but the command didn't accept the password. The problem persisted on Windows once I switched. I spent hours trying to figure out my issue, but failed. I even did cryptanalysis and found the 'passcode' that was used in encryption, but that did me no good since you cannot type in a passcode. You must enter the password, which gets converted into the passcode. With the passcode, I could literally decrypt the file by hand, if only I had a text editor. A hacker without a text editor?  Ultimately, to my shame, I had to look in the forums, guides, etc. To my surprise, I found at least 3 different ways that other players solved this mission. One solved it without a password at all. Another used the password that I was trying all along. The third used a misspelling of the name (with a 'd' instead of a 't'), and for some reason it worked. None of those worked for me.  I have a feeling if I started a new game on Windows, the problem would go away, but I'm not sure if this game is interesting enough to start it all over again.  Review: The game is interesting, and there are plenty of fun tidbits, such as IRC logs with humorous situations. They are repetitive, but worth a laugh. I'm not sure why the executive at KFC spends time on IRC, but whatever. ;) The missions, though, are very repetitive. Hack these ports, download a file. Can't hack a port? Download some command to do it. There is no hacking so much as using tools. You are a script kiddie. I'm not sure I'd play it again, given the possibility of another game-breaking bug, but I was entertained before that happened (even with the other bugs).  Edit: I ended up restarting the game on Windows, and all of the bugs described above were fixed, including the game-ender. I ended up having fun, since I was able to get past the previously completed missions very quickly, and didn't need to nose around the IRC logs, etc. as much as the first play.

I wanted to play a hacking game where I felt like a hacker. This game does that to a small degree. You learn a few basic commands based on linux or unix but it never goes indepth. You're only running exploit hacking programs essentially making you a 'script kiddie'. Like many who played this game, there is a desire for scripts to automate some tasks such as clearing logs or running set programs on a timer. The manual typing of repeated commands becomes a chore after a while.  On the plus side, the story comes from hacking random people's computers and looking through their files to discover their secrets and their everyday lives.
